awd_abstract_narration: This study will result in rigorous inferences of phylogeny for the              marine diatom genus Skeletonema using molecular and morphometric                methods in a cladistic framework.  It is proposed that this genus               can serve as a model system for exploring methods and controversies             in the phylogeny reconstruction of primarily asexual organisms at               lower phylogenetic levels.  The following issues will be explored:              1. Levels of divergence among populations and species measured                  using chloroplast DNA (cpDNA), nuclear rDNA, and a single copy gene             nucDNA gene; 2. Relationships of gene trees and species trees at                lower phylogenetic levels; 3. Concordance of molecular and                      morphological data analyzed using phylogenetic systematic methods.              It is hypothesized that the most primitive members of the genus are             heavily silicified forms endemic to high-light, oligotrophic warm               marine environments and that the most derived members are lightly               silicified forms inhabiting turbid, eutrophic temperate freshwater              and brackish water environments.  The ecological importance and the             wealth of background data available for Skeletonema make it an                  ideal system in which to test hypotheses of adaptation in an                    historical context.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RESEARCH FOUNDATION OF THE CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK
